title: Understand how browsers work, open codespaces from GitHub repo, primitive values in JavaScript, and some boring avatars for your app
description: Dive into the art of Frontend Engineering, learn about the journey of a web page, make interactive web animations with SVG, generate random artwork for your apps, and see if you really know JavaScript strings.

tools.name: Geometric Artwork
tools.description: Generate abstract geometric art using a delightful free tool. Includes 11 different styles and a ton of customization.

tools.name: Boring Avatars
tools.description: Boring avatars is a tiny JavaScript React library that generates custom, SVG-based, round avatars from any username and color palette.

articles.title: The art of Frontend Engineering
articles.description: As the web continues to expand how does Frontend Engineering fit into this landscape and what makes a Frontend Engineer great?

articles.title: Journey of a web page üõ£Ô∏è - How browsers work
articles.description: We are accustomed to opening a webpage in the browser and then almost instantaneously interacting with it. But have you ever wondered what happens behind the scenes in-between you entering a web address in a browser and a web page showing up as a result? Explore with Paulo this and many other questions regarding the journey of a web page in this article.

talks.title: Interactive web animation with SVG
talks.description: Explore with Cassie how you can create interactive animations SVG, and how they provide a link from the world of design to the world of Frontend Development.

tip_of_the_week.description: GitHub has added a new web-based editor with codespaces that can be accessed by pressing ( . ) on any repository on GitHub. It allows you to browse the code and make and commit code changes and many other features of Visual Studio code. Check out how the [Scriptified repo ](https://github.dev/scriptified/scriptified) looks like with it.
tip_of_the_week.title: Open codespaces editor on github

quiz.question: What will be the output of the below snippet?

options.description: Correct! In JavaScript, strings are primitive values, and since [primitive values](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Primitive) are immutable in JavaScript you cannot modify them like you can with objects.
You might wanna check out the docs for [Primitives in JavaScript](https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Glossary/Primitive) and try again.
ah, you're either a bot or just messing with the options here ;)
uh-oh, hard luck! mind re-thinking again?

gif.caption: When they ask you about the progress on your ongoing bug
